item.title: Gran Turismo 7 Update 1.56 Brings Three New Cars and More Today
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/gran-turismo-7-update-156

Sony and Polyphony Digital have announced Gran Turismo 7 Update 1.56, and it's bringing three new cars for you to drive, plus a new body color option for an existing car and more.

Like previous Gran Turismo 7 updates before it, the star of the show when it comes to Update 1.56 is the cars, and this time around, you're getting an "elegant convertible", a multi-purpose truck, and an old reliable rally legend.

First up, it's the BMW Z4 3.0i '03, a convertible sports car that debuted back in 2002. You can see the competition version of this model in action at iconic racetracks like the legendary Nürburgring.

Your next new car in this update is the Mercedes-Benz Unimog Type 411 '62, a rather nifty and angular-looking truck that became popular among a range of outdoorsy folks due to its multi-purpose design.

Last but by no means least, the final car being introduced as part of Gran Turismo 7 Update 1.56 is the Peugeot 205 GTI '88, a rally stalwart that's also a mainstay when it comes to commercially-available hatchback vehicles.

As well as all three of these machines, you can also get your hands on a new body color style for the Mazda3 Gr.4, which gives the car a sleek silver-and-orange look.

Of course, the new update also brings the usual slew of extras with it, including a new Cafe menu, new World Circuits events, and more track compatibility for Gran Turismo 7 AI Sophy, so you can test your skills against it.

If you're not familiar with Gran Turismo 7, it's...well, it's actually the eighth main installment in the Gran Turismo series thanks to the now-delisted Gran Turismo Sport.

Like its predecessors, the game is a sim-style racer that emphasizes verisimilitude. It offers the chance to drive a ton of real-world cars, including the ones listed above, as well as plenty of others from iconic real-world brands.

You can check out Gran Turismo 7 right now on PlayStation.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Pathologic 3: Quarantine Prologue Gets March Release Date and New Trailer
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/pathologic-3-quarantine-release-date

Developer Ice-Pick Lodge and publisher HypeTrain Digital have revealed the release date for upcoming not-quite-a-demo Pathologic 3: Quarantine, a free-to-play prologue that will introduce the world of the game.

Revealed back in December, Quarantine will be arriving for PC via Steam on March 17th, giving what the two studios call "a chilling glimpse into the dark and immersive world of Pathologic 3".

Pathologic 3: Quarantine will tell the story of how Daniil Dankovsky, also known as the Bachelor, came to leave his "acclaimed lab" and kick off the events of Pathologic 3 proper. Quarantine will also introduce the core gameplay mechanics that will make up the basis of Pathologic 3.

As Ice-Pick and HypeTrain tell it, Pathologic 3: Quarantine will ask you to "examine patients, uncover strange secrets, and make first steps towards defeating Death". That's a pretty tall order for a prologue demo.

You'll be able to examine and diagnose patients with the mysterious Sand Plague, but you'll also be prying into their personal lives to see what kind of unsavory secrets they're hiding.

As you play, you'll also be building Dankovsky's mental map of the world around him; the two studios say the Bachelor is a "sharp mind in search of the truth", and it's that very truth you'll have to uncover throughout Quarantine.

You can check out the release date reveal trailer for Pathologic 3: Quarantine right here.

If you're not familiar with Pathologic 3, it's the third game in the Pathologic series, although technically, it's actually sort of the first.

Announced in October, Pathologic 3 is actually an expanded and revised version of the long-awaited Pathologic 2 Bachelor Route, which was intended as an expansion for the second game but which appears to have taken on a life of its own, appropriately enough for Pathologic.

It gets more complicated, though, because Pathologic 2 is sort of an expanded and reworked version of the original Pathologic. It's best to think of each game in the series as a reimagining of the first rather than a true sequel.

In any case, Pathologic 3 is due to arrive on PC sometime this year. The free Quarantine demo-slash-prologue will be available on March 17th.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
